title: If I file bankruptcy is this will affect my wife because she is the earning member and we are not in good relation?
question: I have $90000 in debt including a 4 years lease obligation to a store. I lost all money in my business and I owe another 79000 to my wife and she is asking me that back.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy means test,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt
answers:
There are several issues to go over with an experienced bankruptcy attorney. 1) As long as you are married you are limited to the "standard exemptions" rather than the "wild card exemptions" unless your wife agrees or files with you which sounds unlikely. This may not be a problem or it can be a real problem in filing bankruptcy. 2) If you or your spouse are contemplating divorce, it is vital that you meet with a bankruptcy attorney BEFORE you do a marital settlement agreement or have an order that you pay any particular debt. If the order happens before you file a bankruptcy, you may be stuck "indemnifying" your spouse if she pays a debt you were ordered to pay. That is not true if you file bankruptcy before a family law court makes such an order the bankruptcy keeps the court from doing such an order. 3) If you file a bankruptcy, you may get to choose which assets are exempt (protected) and which are not exempted. 4) There are major differences as to how you are treated under the "means test" depending on whether you are separated and physically living apart. The same is true about whether a divorce proceeding has been started. 5) Filing bankruptcy will include all of your assets AND all community property including her half. 6) Your situation is very dependant on how long you have been married, if you or your spouse owns a house, and so much more. that this only scratches the surface.

Do yourself a huge favor and see a quality bankruptcy attorney to find out what can be done for you and what is protected. Your case would be filed in the Bankruptcy Court in Sacramento. I would recommend you find a quality bankruptcy attorney by looking at Avvo's ratings for Sacramento attorneys.

You could also look at the CA State bar website for a Certified Bankruptcy Law Specialist in Sacramento. I have provided a link to the state bar below. You may have to "cut and paste" it into your search bar.

Another potential source for finding a good attorney would be through a search of the National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys (NACBA.org) to find a good local attorney. Again, I have provided a link below. Again you may have to "cut and paste."

Most attorneys will give you are free initial consultation.

No matter how good an attorney is rated, if you are not comfortable with the attorney when you meet, move on to another attorney. Also, if the attorney uses a paralegal to do the initial appointment, move on because you are just a number and a dollar sign. If this is how you are treated when they are trying to get your money, you can be certain it is not going to get better after they get your money.

Do NOT use an attorney that does anything other than bankruptcy and consumer law and/or foreclosure law. Part-time bankruptcy attorneys are, sadly, almost never expert enough to do the job right. This is a specialized field and you should go with an attorney who practices solely in that specialty. Never hire to veterinarian's assistant to do brain surgery on you and never hire a non-specialist to do a specialists job. Get the right attorney to begin with.

Choose based on skill rather than price. A bad attorney will cost you way more in the long run.

I hope this helps you.
California State Bar Certified Specialist Search
http://members.calbar.ca.gov/search/ls_search.aspx

National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys
http://network.nacba.org/advanced-search
Looks to me like you need both a bankruptcy and a dicvorce consult to review all of your options. Good luck to you.

You state you are not in good relations with your wife, are you living separate or apart? You should seek a consultation with a knowledgeable bankruptcy attorney in your area, now. Most have a free consultation.
You can file w/o wife but her income must be included in the Means Test to determine your eligibility.
